page.title: 16History- Rode and Southwick.
page.content: The mill at Tellisford, on a Roman site, finished its useful life in the 19th century as a flocking mill which shredded rags for mattresses, when it burnt down. The villages were much involved with the weaving trade until 1820. In 1860 there was a famous murder at Langham House, involving the Kent family; a case still studied by law students. Southwick toll gate, in use at that time, is now planted with trees and has a seat provided by the Womens Institute. Rode is thought to have had witches in medieval times as a stone circle still exists under houses in the village centre. A further indication is that 3 old inns were The White Hart, The Red Lion and The Green Man. The 14th century church of St. Lawrence is some way out of the village. By the River Frome there are World War II pillboxes.
